bibl.title: Letter from [Henry Rose Carter] to Frederick F. Russell, May 13, 1924

div1.p: Carter believes that there has been no yellow fever in the Asia. He discusses the exportation of yellow fever by ship.

div1.head: Letter from [Henry Rose Carter] to Frederick F. Russell, May 13, 1924
div1.opener:
I. H. B.
Russell
/LC
2121 California St., N. W.,
Washington, D. C.,
May 13, 1924.
Dear Doctor Russell:
div1.p:
In answer to your letter of May 12th., enclosing copy of one
of Caldwell's, relative to yellow fever in the East Indies, I would
say:

It is qyite certain (I think one can leave out the “quite”)
that there never has been yellow fever in the Far East. Considering
the universal prevalence of its vector there and the extremely dense
population, it would have produced and, from time to time, be pro-
ducing, the most horrible epidemics and could not by any possibility
have been overlooked.

So far as the “Mal de Siam” is concerned, its reporter, Labat,
said it came from Pernambuco, where the Oriflamme--the vessel that
brought it to Martinique, stopped “for refreshing.” “A bicha,”
unquestionably yellow fever, was first epidemic in Pernambuco and
Bahia in 1686 and showed itself in the latter city, in new comers,
for several years thereafter. The “Oriflamme” was in Pernambuco in
/89 or /90. It may have been introduced into Pernambuco from the
Cape de Verde Islands by the expedition of Freyre de Andrade, but
but
-2-
bhis is not certain, only probable.

I have no doubt that Chile did quarantine the Far East for
yellow fever and it may well be that vessels therefrom brought cases
of malaria to the nitrate country and, if there be sufficient active
Anopheles there (I doubt if there be) malaria may have spread therefrom.
One of my men at Chandeleur Quarantine, Alfred Johanson, reported
that he had yellow fever when a soldier in the Dutch army at Sou-
robaya, but he had it again (sin falta!) at Chandeleur.

I am glad to get Caldwell's letter, however. All such things
are interesting, as was Spinden's account of the epidemics of yel-
low fever (matlazuhuati) “when it froze,” on the Mexican plateau,
or Ulloa's of the one “in the time of ices,” in the Andean high-
lands.
div1.closer:
Very truly yours, Dr. F. F. Russell, General Director,
International Health Board,
61 Broadway,
New York, N. Y.
